H0.text: Oil, air, and rock are examples of matter that can take the shape of a container.

H1.text: Water, air, and milk are examples of matter that can take the shape of a container.

H2.text: The list “sand, ice, and wood” includes only examples of matter that can take the shape of a container.

H3.text: Nail, stick, and paper are examples of matter that can take the shape of a container.

A4.text: A gas is a compressible fluid. Not only will a gas conform to the shape of its container but it will also expand to fill the container.

A5.text: In a liquid, the particles remain close together but can move past one another, allowing the substance to maintain a fixed volume while adapting to the shape of its container.

A6.text: Gas particles spread apart or diffuse in order to homogeneously distribute themselves throughout any container.

A7.text: Gas is a state of matter with neither fixed volume nor fixed shape.
